description: Dive into "Florence: Capture the City‚Äôs Timeless Beauty" ‚Äî a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Florence: Capture the City‚Äôs Timeless Beauty

places.generalDescription: Ponte Vecchio is a charming medieval bridge with a rich history dating back to Roman times. It is renowned for its unique shops selling jewelry and souvenirs. On the northern side of the river, visitors can explore major Florence attractions such as the Duomo, Giotto's Bell Tower, Piazza della Signoria, Basilica of Santa Maria Novella, and more. The bridge has endured significant events throughout history including reconstruction after a devastating flood and surviving World War II.

sources.snippet: You have to think a little out of the box for the next of our most Instagrammable places in Florence ‚Äì rather than visiting it, you want to visit somewhere parallel to it!. The Ponte Vecchio is unquestionably one of Florence‚Äôs most famous sights, and it‚Äôs definitely one that you‚Äôll want to capture and put on your feed, showing off your lovely travels to the envying masses. But there‚Äôs three ways you can take a good photo there, and only one of them shows the bridge off to its fullest.
sources.shortName: The 22 Must-See Instagrammable Places in Florence!

sources.snippet: We loved visiting the Ponte Vecchio very early in the morning prior to dawn when the trader stalls were closed and the atmosphere serene. The bridge is beautiful and is steeped in history. Best photo locations in Florence tip: For less crowded shots of the Ponte Vecchio during the day try the Corridoio Vasariano, a columned corridor on the north side of the Arno river between the Uffizi Gallery and the Ponte Vecchio.
sources.siteName: The Whole World Is A Playground
sources.shortName: The Best Photo Locations in Florence (with map)

sources.snippet: The centrepiece of Florence is the famous ‚ÄúDuomo,‚Äù made up of the  Cathedral of Santa Maria del Fiore and Campanile di Giotto (Giotto‚Äôs Bell Tower).. Climb to the top of either the massive dome designed by Filippo Brunelleschi or the campanile for unbeatable views of the city from high above. Even just admiring the intricate marble facade from the Piazza del Duomo at sunrise is an unforgettable experience.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Places to Take Photos in Florence

sources.snippet: The ‚ÄòOld Bridge‚Äô is another Florence icon, a street of shops built onto what has become one of the most famous and beautiful  bridges in Europe. It‚Äôs also one of the most recognisable  landmarks in Italy, its jewellery and craft stores busy with shoppers most of the day. It looks better from a short distance, its distinctive yellow hue glowing in the early morning and late evening light.
sources.shortName: 10 Best Photo Locations In Florence

sources.snippet: Il Ponte Vecchio, translating to ‚ÄúOld Bridge‚Äù in Italian, has connected the Duomo and Palazzo Pitti neighborhoods above the Arno River since the 12th century. The Vasari corridor runs above the bridge, connecting Palazzo Pitti all the way to Piazza della Signoria. The bridge has survived countless floods, most famously the flood of 1333 where it was almost completely destroyed.
sources.shortName: 23 Florence Instagram Spots to Visit on Your Italy Trip

sources.snippet: You‚Äôve probably seen thousands of photos of the Ponte Vecchio, the most photographed bridge in the city and one of its best known landmarks. The ideal spot to take pictures of the ‚ÄòOld Bridge‚Äô is standing on the adjacent bridge Ponte Santa Trinita. The backdrop to the Ponte Vecchio is simply perfect, with the hills gently rising to embrace Florence.
sources.shortName: 10 Top Places to take Photos in Florence

sources.snippet: Confession time: I didn‚Äôt originally have the Ponte Vecchio on my list of Florence photography locations. We were walking from Piazza della Signoria towards Piazzale Michelangelo, and while walking down Piazza dei Giudici, about to cross the Arno River, we figured ‚ÄúHey, why not?. ‚Äù And decided to grab a quick picture with the Ponte Vecchio.

sources.shortName: The 10 Most Instagrammable Spots in Florence ‚Äî Notes From Here

sources.snippet: Ponte Vecchio is the oldest bridge in all of Florence and is known as the bridge of gold. Not because it‚Äôs made of gold, but due to all the jewelry stores on the bridge. We are not talking a $50 bracelet; we are talking about a custom $100,000 bracelet that when you enter the shop, the door locks behind you, before the one in front opens.
sources.shortName: 29 Instagrammable Spots in Florence

sources.snippet: Take a stroll across a few of Florence‚Äôs famous bridges for some of the best views in town. Lined with jewellers‚Äô shops, the beautiful Ponte Vecchio ‚Äì ‚ÄúOld Bridge‚Äù ‚Äì is synonymous with the city itself. So much so that it has become a character in some of the best films set in Italy (including my favourite, A Room with a View).
sources.shortName: 13 Stunning Views Of Florence You'll Adore

sources.snippet: The Ponte Vecchio is perfect for some empty street pictures while doing a photoshoot in Florence. Please be extra cautious if walking around here when it is empty ‚Äì it can be relatively dangerous at times. If you spot anything sketchy, avoid it altogether and photograph on one of the bridges just one block over!
sources.shortName: The Best Photo Spots in Florence

sources.snippet: The Ponte Vecchio is one of the most famous bridges in Florence. This medieval bridge crosses the Arno River and is lined with jewelry stores and souvenir shops. It‚Äôs a popular spot for tourists and locals alike, so be prepared to come here early if you want to snap some Instagram-worthy photos!

sources.snippet: Picture unobstructed views of Florence‚Äôs entire skyline from the hillside balcony terrace including the iconic Duomo cathedral dome to the medieval Ponte Vecchio bridge to the Palazzo Vecchio fortress and surrounding red rooftops. Golden hour sunsets prompt flawless image illuminations.

sources.snippet: This place gets REALLY crowded during the day - and it‚Äôs just plain busy at night - but there‚Äôs something about it. There are usually musicians playing for tips and just a nice, good vibe hanging around this place. Come hang out, take some pics, and enjoy the local scene.

sources.snippet: Ponte Vecchio or ‚ÄúThe Old Bridge‚Äù is the oldest and most famous bridge in Florence. The current bridge was built in 1345, but its history dates back to Roman times when it was made of wood. There are many shops along the bridge.

sources.snippet: When Florence is mentioned one of the first things that comes to mind is the Ponte Vecchio. The shop-lined bridge painted in warm tones of honey and gold. A trip to Florence without a photo of the Ponte Vecchio would be a shame.

places.generalDescription: The Cathedral of Santa Maria del Fiore, also known as the Duomo of Florence, is a 1200s landmark featuring a red-tiled dome, colored marble facade, and elegant Giotto tower. Visiting this complex allows you to experience multiple must-see sights in one go.

sources.snippet: The Santa Maria del Fiore Cathedral, also known as the Florence Cathedral or simply the Duomo, is one of the best photo spots in Florence. With its imposing dome and intricate details, this Gothic cathedral is a must-see for any visitor to the city. The three types of rocks (green metamorphic serpentine, white Carrara marble, and red limestone) used to cover the entire basilica give it a unique and striking look.
sources.shortName: 20 Best Florence Instagram Spots

sources.snippet: The cathedral itself is incredible both inside and outside and easily worthy of a photo spot of its own. The beautiful marble exterior and red roof make for some nice images and the interior is beautiful too. The facade of the cathedral is full of intricate details and splashes of colour so it‚Äôs worth taking the time to pick out some of the details.
sources.siteName: The Whole World Is A Playground
sources.shortName: The Best Photo Locations in Florence (with map)

sources.snippet: This cathedral needs to be at the top of your list of Instagrammable spots in Florence to visit!. Everyone has a photo in front of this stunning cathedral, and you should be no exception. From the unique exterior design to the duomo that dominates the Florence skyline, it‚Äôs impossible to take a bad photo here.
sources.shortName: 29 Instagrammable Spots in Florence

sources.snippet: Climbing to the top of cathedrals in Europe always offer unbeatable views over the cities below. The Duomo of Florence however goes one step further. You are barely restricted at the top and have to hold on as you delicately tread around the very tip of the dome.

reviews.text:
An inspiring experience at the Duomo in Florence, it was truly breathtaking! The stunning architecture, intricate details, and rich history left us in awe. Loved the history and beauty of italian history.
The property itself is a masterpiece of Renaissance architecture, with the terracotta-tiled dome designed by Filippo Brunelleschi being a highlight. The intricate marble facades, stunning stained-glass windows, and ornate sculptures added to the overall grandeur of the complex. A must see beauty of art and history.
Encourage visiting the Duomo, especially with a guided tour, to appreciate its beauty, history, and significance. It's an experience that will leave you with lasting memories of Florence magnificent beauty.

Absolutely beautiful, the cathedral looked amazing and it was very grandiose.

I loved to see the use of colors that they applied. You really cannot grasp just how big the cathedral and the dome are until you stand close to it. Heck we were even able to see it from when our plane was going to land.

The outside of the building is a sight to be hold superb and worth the visit alone.
The inside not so much quite bland for such a huge building. The fresco on the ceiling is wonderful
Plus if you want to see climb the dome or the bell tower it's extra charges as is the crypt.To see the check on site and book well in advance .
Advisable to book in advance to visit the cathedral inside

places.generalDescription: David, the renowned Renaissance-era marble sculpture by Michelangelo, is a masterpiece that depicts the biblical character David. The statue is celebrated for its exceptional detail and accuracy in portraying the human form. While the original can be found at the Galleria dell'Accademia, a replica stands at the entrance of Palazzo Vecchio. Visitors to Florence can also admire other impressive works by Michelangelo inside the gallery.

sources.snippet: Michelangelo‚Äôs  David is one of the most famous statues in the world. The original can be seen in the Accademia, and there is a replica in Piazza della Signoria, near the entrance to the Palazzo Vecchio. It makes for an better photographic subject outside, where, for an hour or two early afternoon each day, a shaft of sunlight squeezes down Piazzale degli Uffizi, illuminating the side of the statue.
sources.shortName: 10 Best Photo Locations In Florence

sources.snippet: You‚Äôll have to be ready to queue no matter what time of the day you come at, but this piece by Michelangelo is instantly recognisable by anybody around the world and will light up your Insta feed. places.generalDescription: The Basilica of Santa Croce in Florence is a stunning Neo-Gothic Franciscan church that holds an array of historical and artistic treasures. It features remarkable Giotto frescoes, Vasari's Last Supper, and the tombs of renowned figures such as Michelangelo, Galileo, and Machiavelli. The church is part of Florence's rich cultural heritage, alongside other iconic landmarks like Santa Maria del Fiore and the Uffizi.

sources.snippet: Staying on the theme of churches which are also Florence photography spots (buckle up: there‚Äôs a lot of them!), make your way to the Basilica di Santa Croce for another quiet spot with a touch of elegance. The Basilica is one of the city‚Äôs most prestigious resting places, and you‚Äôll find some giants of Italian history getting their eternal rest in the building, which is well worth visiting. Pay your respects to the artistic genius of Michelanglelo, the scientific wonder that is Galileo, or the dodgy scheming of Machiavelli.
sources.shortName: The 22 Must-See Instagrammable Places in Florence!

sources.snippet: Basilica di Santa Croce is lesser known than the famous Duomo, but that makes it worth the visit, since this church is less busy. It‚Äôs commonly known as the Temple of the Italian Glories because of the influential architects and artists that are buried there ‚Äì Michelangelo, Machiavelli, and Galileo‚Äôs tombs can all be found at this Basilica. With a similar exterior design as the Cattedrale di Santa Maria del Fiore, you‚Äôre guaranteed to have a magnificent backdrop for a photo!
sources.shortName: 29 Instagrammable Spots in Florence

sources.snippet: The Basilica di Santa Croce is a Franciscan church with a beautiful neo-Gothic marble facade, located in the square with the same name. Even though Piazza di Santa Croce is not as busy as Piazza del Duomo, you should come here either early in the morning or late during the evening when there‚Äôs less traffic for an awesome photo opportunity.

places.generalDescription: Palazzo Vecchio, originally built to house the city's government officials and later transformed into the Medici family's residence, is a 13th-century fortified palace in Florence. It boasts lavishly decorated chambers, ornate courtyards, and a towering presence atop the Piazza della Signoria. Inside, visitors can explore secret passages, admire frescoed ceilings, and marvel at well-preserved artworks that offer insight into Florence's rich history under powerful families like the Medici dynasty.

sources.snippet: In the centre of Florence is this majestic piazza where the Palazzo Vecchio towers over the cobblestones below. An open air museum, free entry and fountains filled with statues‚Ä¶including Tritone himself, this piazza is your one stop photo spot. Usually filled with people, it‚Äôs a great chance to test your creative skills and take alternative angles of the buildings whether it be in puddle reflections, by framing them with other historical details or by arriving at a time when the piazza is a little emptier‚Ä¶think sunrise!
sources.siteName: Photo Tips, Creative Photography + Travel Guides - The Wandering Lens
sources.shortName: A Guide to the Best Photo Spots

sources.snippet: This building used to be the seat of power in Florence ‚Äì and with its modern designation as one of the most Instagrammable places in Florence, it‚Äôs seat of awesome Insta POWER!. (a little too dramatic? Okay, maybe a little too dramatic.). But it‚Äôs true that this used to be the main HQ for the head honchos of Florence, and aside from seeing a few dramatic incidents in its time (many of them ending up with various people getting murdered in an infinitesimal variety of ways), it also used to be the palace of the Medici.
sources.shortName: The 22 Must-See Instagrammable Places in Florence!

sources.snippet: Palazzo Vecchio is probably best known for its copy of Michelangelo‚Äôs statue of David, and after Brunelleschi‚Äôs Dome and Giotto‚Äôs Campanile is the next most recognizable monument towering over Florence‚Äôs skyline. Apart from housing a museum, the Palazzo Vecchio also has a climbable bell tower that many people don‚Äôt take advantage of. There are a number of ticket options including one for those who only want to climb the bell tower and skip the museum (‚Ç¨10), or you can access both the museum and tower for ‚Ç¨14.
sources.shortName: 8 Places to Visit for the Best Views in Florence in Italy

sources.snippet: The Torre di Arnolfo, the slender tower of the Palazzo Vecchio in Piazza Signora, is a great viewpoint. After a visit to the history-filled palace, you should climb the tower and admire Florence and its fabulous buildings from a different angle. TIP => If you love art, you might want to spend a bit of time at the Loggia dei Lanzi in Piazza Signoria, and capture all the beauty and drama of its bronze and marble statues.
sources.shortName: 10 Top Places to take Photos in Florence

sources.snippet: Far less crowded than the more iconic views of Florence but equally stunning, the Palazzo Vecchio is one of our personal favorite photography locations in Florence, Italy!. From the top of this tower, you‚Äôll be rewarded with a magnificent view of the Duomo from the side, allowing you to easily capture how magnificent the building is as well as how clearly it dwarfs the rest of the city by comparison.
sources.shortName: 21+ Most Instagrammable Photo Spots in Florence

sources.snippet: Right next to the Loggia Della Signoria is this Palazzo, and while I did not take the full tour, I think you will find plenty here to enjoy and photograph, especially if you enjoy architecture. This is the entry hall sort of thing, and it's gorgeous. Outside of the Palazzo, in Piazza Della Signoria, is a full-size replica of the David statue from the Accademia.

reviews.text: Ma favorite place in Firenze, always! I love the Palazzo Vecchio as it's very quiet and not so crowded compared to other famous places in Firenze or Italy. I also love the fact that there are some signs and descriptions in each room to explain the purpose of the room and the paintings and other objects inside the rooms. The staff working there is very nice and helpful too.

Went by but didn't go inside, just looked around the free parts. The building is cool and has a lot of history, but mostly felt like a tourist spot. Worth a quick look if you're already in the area, but nothing I'd plan around.

Really cool to see the amazing art displayed on the walls inside the hall. Walking inside not knowing what I would see just to be amazed by the craftsmanship. I would recommend it for any one coming for art and history, but if your not much into art and have visited alot of museums throughout the day then it won't be worth it for you. However for my friends and I enjoyed visiting and seeing this place.

places.generalDescription: The Uffizi Galleries, located just a short stroll from the iconic Ponte Vecchio, is a 16th-century building that houses an extensive collection of Primitive and Renaissance paintings and masterpieces. This renowned museum welcomes over two million visitors annually who come to admire ancient sculptures and historic paintings spanning from the Middle Ages to modern times.

sources.snippet: The Uffizi Gallery is one of the most popular places to visit in Florence and is also a great spot for Florence photos. The first photo location is the Piazza in front of the Uffizi Gallery. This symmetrical columned courtyard is an iconic image of Florence and it best shot at night or very early in the morning.
sources.siteName: The Whole World Is A Playground
sources.shortName: The Best Photo Locations in Florence (with map)

sources.snippet: This may be my favorite museum anywhere, although I will admit I tend to really like Renaissance art, and this is the home of it. You will find work by Botticelli, Caravaggio, Michelangelo and even Leonardo da Vinci here. Be sure and book a ticket on line in advance because the lines get really long.
sources.shortName: Top Photo Spots in Florence, Italy

sources.snippet: The main reason for stepping foot over the threshold of the Uffizi Galleries is to ogle its collection of world-famous Florentine Renaissance art. But did you know that this gallery is home to one of the best photography spots in Florence?. Make your way to one or both of these locations.

sources.snippet: The Uffizi Gallery will take you back in time to the Italian Renaissance. With some of the most important and famous art collections on display, it‚Äôs well worth checking out!. Take a second to look out the windows of the gallery ‚Äì you‚Äôll be pleasantly surprised by the view.
sources.shortName: 29 Instagrammable Spots in Florence

sources.snippet: The Uffizi Gallery is one of the oldest art museums in the world. It was built in the second half of the 16th century to house the offices (uffizi) of the Florentine magistrates. The building was commissioned by the Medici family and designed by Vasari.
sources.shortName: Florence Instagram Spots & Unique Tips For The Best Photos

sources.snippet: It‚Äôs pretty simple, to be honest: it‚Äôs nothing less than one of the very best art galleries in the world.

places.name: Uffizi Galleries

reviews.text: We bought tickets a couple of months before our visit and got them for the earliest time slot possible. Even doing this, I recommend arriving as early as possible. We got to the entrance 15 minutes before the museum opened and there was already a line. That being said, the museum is huge and early in the morning crowds weren't bad at all! We ran right upstairs to the Botticelli rooms, and got to have them all to ourselves. Absolutely amazing. Everything in this museum from the architecture to the artwork itself is beautiful.

Visiting the Uffizi Gallery was a dream come true. I love Tuscany and the Renaissance, and being in the Uffizi Gallery and seeing the works of famous Renaissance artists was like a dream. I had to pinch myself every now and then to remind myself that I was awake and that I was really in the Uffizi Gallery. We were visiting in May, so it was crowded, but I didn't notice it at all, as I was excited and enchanted by the visit and the whole experience. Seeing Botticelli's Primavera and Birth of Venus and Raphael's Madonna of the Goldfinch were experiences in themselves. And when I saw Artemisia Gentileschi's Judith Beheading Holofernes was the icing on the cake. The works of some of my favorite artists in one place and seeing them live was a privilege and an experience that I will always remember. As there was a crowd, we did wait a bit to get in, mostly due to strict security, and it took us approx 15 to 20 min which is completly normal for the time of the month and the popularty of Uffizi. We did have Firenzecard so we only had to book an appoitment for Uffizi Gallery which we did 2 days before the visit so we did save some time. And we also took an appoitment in the morning hours which was a great decison as the crowd got bigger the longer the visit went. You will need several hours for the visit and to not hurry through the gallery, so my advice plan your time well. We took our time to enjoy our visit so were in Uffizi from 09:30 until 12:45. Anyone planning to stay in Tuscany and Florence for more then one or two days, I highly recommend to get the Firenzacard. Makes visits to palazzo, museums and galleries that much easier and pleasent.

An absolutely breathtaking experience! I was so impressed by the incredible collection of famous artworks, and learning about the Medici family's background and legacy made it even more fascinating. Every room holds masterpieces that deserve hours of attention-honestly, even a lifetime wouldn't be enough to truly take in all the details. I only wish I had more time to explore! Plus it was very interesting to see famous Ottoman portraits up there on the ceiling as a Turkish.

places.generalDescription: Brunelleschi's dome is an iconic Renaissance cathedral dome in Florence, designed by Filippo Brunelleschi in the 15th century. The concept for this masterpiece was initiated by the builders of Florence Cathedral in 1296, but it wasn't until Brunelleschi's designs in 1420 that the dome came to life. He ingeniously created a massive octagonal double-shell to support its weight, as buttresses were forbidden in Florence.

sources.snippet: Probably the most popular and well known viewpoint in Florence, people from all over the world flock to climb 463 steps up to the top of the Duomo. For this reason, there are often long lines of visitors waiting to get in (the majority of the climb up is single file only). Nevertheless, once you reach the summit of the Brunelleschi Dome, everything else will fade away and for a moment ‚Äì just a moment ‚Äì all that matters is what‚Äôs in front of you.
sources.shortName: 8 Places to Visit for the Best Views in Florence in Italy

sources.snippet: Brunelleschi‚Äôs Dome is one of the highlights of Florence and also one of the best photo spots in the city. The view from the top looks incredible: the leading lines of the dome roof beneath the viewing platform is one of the iconic shots of Florence. Best photo locations in Florence tip: We didn‚Äôt book in advance and, unfortunately, we were not able to secure a time slot for the dome climb and we missed out on climbing the dome.

sources.shortName: 13 Stunning Views Of Florence You'll Adore

sources.snippet: Climb the nearly 500 stairs for a close-up view of the impressive dome and fantastic views of the Florence skyline. Note: To take a picture of the dome itself, you‚Äôll need to climb Giotto‚Äôs Bell Tower.

places.name: Brunelleschi's dome

reviews.text: The view on top of Brunelleschi's dome is the most beautiful overhead sight of Florence and is well worth the 463 step climb. We had an ample amount of time upon reaching the top of the Dome to take whatever pictures and videos we wanted to and simply enjoy the view before heading back down. The tickets purchased are for specific timeslots and certain numbers of people are able to go up at a time so I would definitely suggest purchasing one online or in advance and not worry about the wait since people are only allowed in at their specific times.

Brunelleschi's Dome is a masterpiece of Renaissance engineering. The climb is about 463 steps through narrow staircases and hidden passages, where you can get close to the frescoes inside the dome. It's a bit tiring, but the reward is the panoramic view of Florence from the very top ‚Äì completely worth the effort!

Mind you, you will be at the top of dome, hence you won't be able to get the clear picture of the dome, but you can easily see the entire city.

Its beautiful monument how our ancestors gave attention to details. Astounding work worth your time to admire it.
Brunelleschi's Dome has 463 steps to the top, a journey that takes approximately 45 minutes to an hour and involves climbing through tight passages within the double-shelled dome.
I have shared few photos of the visual experience inside and on the top of the dome. Once you start climbing you can't climb down in the middle, as you need to use same narrow flight of stairs to the top and climb down.

places.generalDescription: Campanile di Giotto is a renowned Gothic tower in Florence, Italy. It stands at 85 meters tall and is adorned with red, green, and white marble. The tower offers breathtaking panoramic views of the city from its terrace. Situated in Piazza del Duomo, it is part of the major attractions in northern Florence along with the Duomo and Piazza della Signoria.

sources.snippet: While the cupola of the Cathedral of Santa Maria del Fiore (also simply known as the Duomo) is popular to climb, people who didn‚Äôt book tickets in advance or are scared of heights might prefer the view from the bell tower next door!. Not only will climbing Giotto‚Äôs Bell Tower give you amazing views over Florence, but it‚Äôll allow you to get some up-close-and-personal shots of the epic cupola as well!
sources.shortName: 21+ Most Instagrammable Photo Spots in Florence

sources.snippet: We‚Äôre heading back to the Duomo for the next of our Instagrammable places in Florence!. But my favourite time of day to capture your next shot is at night, when the cathedral and its surrounds are beautifully lit. Plus you‚Äôll get to see a bit of street life, and the local Italians going for an evening stroll ‚Äì they‚Äôre much too smart to go out in the heat of the day, unlike us weirdo visitors!
sources.shortName: The 22 Must-See Instagrammable Places in Florence!

sources.snippet: Located in the middle of the city, we recommend climbing the 414 steps to the top of Giotto‚Äôs Bell Tower. At the top, you‚Äôll have a 360-degree panoramic view of the entire city. If you don‚Äôt want to work up a sweat climbing to the top, taking a photo at the bottom of the tower is equally impressive.
sources.shortName: 29 Instagrammable Spots in Florence

sources.snippet: Who said viewing points were only beautiful once you get to the top?. Giotto‚Äôs bell tower is one of the buildings which rises upwards and seems to get lost in the infinite sky. Look around from the bottom to the top, focussing on the details and the colours of the marble of the imposing building.

sources.snippet: Giotto‚Äôs Bell Tower (Giotto‚Äôs Campanile) is a free-standing tower in Florence, Italy, that was designed by the Florentine architect Giotto di Bondone. The tower is part of the Florence Cathedral (Duomo) complex and is decorated with the same intricate details.
sources.shortName: 20 Best Florence Instagram Spots

sources.snippet: Giotto‚Äôs Bell Tower is the Florence Instagram spot you can‚Äôt miss. From the top, you‚Äôll have a 360¬∞ view of the Florence skyline. And you will have the best view of the cathedral‚Äôs red dome.
sources.shortName: Florence Instagram Spots & Unique Tips For The Best Photos

places.name: Giotto's Bell Tower

reviews.text:
Giotto's Campanile is one of the most iconic structures in Florence's skyline and a must-visit for anyone exploring the city. Part of the Cathedral complex, this 14th-century bell tower was begun by the renowned artist and architect Giotto di Bondone in 1334 and completed after his death.
Be sure to book your tickets online in advance, as entrance is limited and demand is high, especially during peak season. Without a reservation, it's unlikely you'll get in.
The climb to the top involves more than 400 narrow steps-there's no elevator, and the staircase can feel quite tight, which may be challenging for some. But the reward at the top is simply stunning: a panoramic view over Florence that includes an unbeatable close-up of Brunelleschi's dome.
Aside from the view, the tower itself is a masterpiece of Gothic architecture. The intricate exterior features polychrome marble panels and detailed decorations that deserve close attention. A physically demanding visit, but without a doubt worth every step.

Giotto's Bell Tower is one of the highlights of Florence ‚Äì the architecture is stunning up close, and climbing it is a great experience. The staircase is quite narrow and steep, but manageable if you take your time. The effort is well worth it for the panoramic views over the Duomo and the city!

Absolutely must visit!!

Giotto's Bell Tower is an absolute gem in the heart of Florence! The architecture is breathtaking, with its intricate marble panels and vibrant Gothic design that truly stands out against the city skyline. Climbing the tower is a rewarding experience-the views from the top are panoramic and provide a unique perspective of the Duomo, Florence rooftops, and the surrounding hills.

The climb is a bit steep and involves quite a few steps, so wear comfortable shoes, but every step is worth it. Don't forget your camera-there are plenty of spots for incredible photos. The historical and artistic details along the way make it more than just a climb; it's like walking through a living piece of art history.

places.address: Piazza del Duomo, 43¬∞46'22"N 11¬∞15'20"E, 50122 Firenze FI, Italy

places.generalDescription: In the heart of Florence, Italy, stands the Basilica of Santa Maria Novella, a 15th-century Dominican church renowned for its stunning frescoes by Gothic and early Renaissance masters. Situated on the northern side of the river, this area is home to some of Florence's major attractions.

sources.snippet: Santa Maria Novella is one of the finest churches in Florence, and the city‚Äôs main station, named Firenze SMN on timetables, is located just behind it and named after it. The main shot of this handsome Florence church is the marble front, which, unusually, is at the east end of the church (as opposed to the usual west end) so it‚Äôs a morning rather than evening shot. This former monastery church is filled with artistic treasures, including the frescoes by Domenico Ghirlandaio in the Cappella Tornabuoni.
sources.shortName: 10 Best Photo Locations In Florence

sources.snippet: If you‚Äôre looking for Florence photography locations, it doesn‚Äôt get much better than the Basilica di Santa Maria Novella. This 13th century convent turned basilica is often overlooked on the typical tourist‚Äôs itinerary, but its gorgeous facade is one of the best Florence photo spots. It‚Äôs also the only church in Florence with its original interior.

sources.snippet: This quaint church is not the most popular or busiest in the city, so you should use that to your advantage. The exterior of the church is stunning, especially when the garden‚Äôs flowers are in full bloom. Without question, this church encompasses everything that is Florence.

reviews.text:
Hidden gem in Bergamo.
One of the most beautiful churches I've ever visited. Incredible art, detailed interiors, and a quiet atmosphere. Don't miss the wooden choir stalls!

May 2025. Seems to be one of the major church destinations in Florence. Conveniently located near the train station. Another case of me liking the exterior more. The interior is still worth visiting though.

Stunning building from the outside.
But I was a little underwhelmed inside. Apart from the fresco  which was the was the highlight.If you want to climb the bell tower or the dome and go down the crypt you have to pay extra.
Check well in advance if you want to climb the dome.It does get busy.

places.generalDescription: Basilica di San Miniato is a stunning 11th-century church located on a hilltop in Florence, offering breathtaking city views. It is renowned for its gleaming Romanesque facade and medieval interiors, making it one of the most exquisite examples of Romanesque architecture in Tuscany. Visitors can explore the church and the adjacent Olivetan monastery for free, although access may be challenging for those with limited mobility.

sources.snippet: If you want to escape the crowds this is where you want to go. The actual viewpoint is below the steps of the Basilica. For the best photos, you need a good camera with zoom.

reviews.text:
Located above the Piazza Michelangelo this church has a great view.  The cemetery is beautiful and many of the monuments feature recognizable names. Inside the church has an understated grace that still inspires awe. All in all a lovely visit and a
recommended stop.

The church was undergoing repair in February 2025 and the front facade and part of the nave was scaffolded. The architect and contractor are maintaining public access and in fact are providing exemplary information boards about the work and offering occasional conducted tours.
The church is impressive inside and out and learning how the fabric is being repaired is fascinating.
The work will go on for many months.
May 2025. Arguably a better view than Piazzale Michelangelo. The church itself is probably very nice, but it was under heavy renovation when we visited.

places.generalDescription: Basilica di San Lorenzo, a landmark Renaissance church in Florence, is known as the burial place of the Medici family. The church features an unfinished facade designed by Michelangelo and a library he also designed. It was originally built in the 4th century and later transformed into a magnificent Renaissance building by Filippo Brunelleschi from 1377 to 1446. Inside, visitors can admire Brunelleschi's Sagrestia Vecchia with sculptural decoration by Donatello.

sources.snippet: The last of Florence‚Äôs awesomely pretty churches, this was actually a pretty important place back in the day. It was the ‚Äòhome‚Äô church of the Medici family, the bankers who rose to lead the city, and have popes and royalty in the family. Consequently there‚Äôs a huge number of them getting their eternal rest in the basilica; you can visit their tombs, and gaze upon the people who truly made Florence the city it is today.
sources.shortName: The 22 Must-See Instagrammable Places in Florence!

sources.snippet: This church is said to be one of the oldest in Florence, and its unfinished fa√ßade makes it that much more unique. While the outside is not the best for taking photos, the interior is beautiful, especially the Laurentian Library staircase that was designed by Michelangelo. Featured Traveler: @marine__cll

places.name: Basilica di San Lorenzo

reviews.text: A very beautiful basilica, both the main building and the crypt which hosts a small museum of sorts. Some stunning murals and sculptures. Not too crowded.

Pretty disappointing I thought.  For 9 euros I was expecting something pretty spectacular but it is nothing exceptional.  I thought the courtyard was the best part.  The basement isn't a crypt but a museum of altar pieces and robes.  There is a toilet in the bookstore (off the courtyard) that costs 1 euro but it only takes 1 and 2 euro coins.  Just duck under the turnstile to get in.

Trivia - The front of the building looks odd since it is the back wall to a marble facade that was never added.

The Basilica di San Lorenzo (Basilica of St. Lawrence) is one of the largest churches of Florence, Italy, situated at the centre of the main market district of the city, and it is the burial place of all the principal members of the Medici family from Cosimo il Vecchio to Cosimo III. It is one of several churches that claim to be the oldest in Florence, having been consecrated in 393 AD,[1] at which time it stood outside the city walls. For three hundred years it was the city's cathedral, before the official seat of the bishop was transferred to Santa Reparata.

San Lorenzo was the parish church of the Medici family. In 1419, Giovanni di Bicci de' Medici offered to finance a new church to replace an eleventh-century Romanesque rebuilding. Filippo Brunelleschi, the leading Renaissance architect of the first half of the fifteenth century, was commissioned to design it, but the building, with alterations, was not completed until after his death. The church is part of a larger monastic complex that contains other important architectural and artistic works: the Old Sacristy (Sagresta Vecchia) by Brunelleschi and having interior decoration and sculpture by Donatello; the Laurentian Library by Michelangelo; the Medici Chapels, two structures that include the New Sacristy (Sagrestia Nuova) based on Michelangelo's designs; and the larger Cappella dei Principi ("Chapel of the Princes") being a collaboration between the family and architects.

places.generalDescription: Fontana del Porcellino is a famous bronze fountain in Florence, located near Piazza della Repubblica. The fountain features a bronze wild boar with water dripping from its mouth. According to legend, rubbing the boar's snout ensures your return to Florence, while another legend suggests making a wish and placing a coin in the statue's mouth for it to come true if it falls between the grates.

sources.snippet: Fontana del Porcellino is located relatively close to Piazza della Repubblica and it consists of a bronze wild boar with water dripping from its mouth. One legend says that if you rub its snout, you will return to Florence, while another says to think of a wish, then put a coin in the statue‚Äôs mouth and if it falls directly between the grates, then you‚Äôll get your wish come true. Since right behind the fountain there‚Äôs a market, I think the best frame is from the side as you comply with either legend (or both).
sources.shortName: 20 Best Florence Instagram Spots

sources.snippet: Located at the back of Mercator Nuovo is the Fontana Del Porcellino. With its shiny, polished snout the Fontana Del Porcellino is one of the iconic images of Florence. As the story goes, visitors to Florence should place a coin in the piglet‚Äôs mouth, letting it fall into the grate of good luck and to rub his snout to return to Florence.

places.name: Fontana del Porcellino

reviews.text:
A small attraction that's still interesting.

It's located on the corner of a trade fair, where you can buy clothing or souvenirs.

I recommend going early, before 9:00 a.m. local time, as later there are many tourists and tour groups trying to toss coins, and it's impossible to get close comfortably.

The story behind the statue is truly beautiful.
The area is truly magical and mesmerizing. There are so many shops and places to eat. Highly recommend!

Well, needed some luck! Visited early in the morning (07:30) on a weekday and no one else was there. Didn't get the coin directly in the grate but did rub the boar's nose to ensure I return to Florence one day!

places.generalDescription: Palazzo Pitti is a grand Renaissance royal palace in Florence that houses an extensive collection of Italian and European masterpieces. It comprises six museums, including the Palatine Gallery, which boasts twenty-eight rooms filled with late Renaissance and Baroque art by renowned artists such as Raphael, Andrea del Sarto, Rubens, and Tintoretto. The Gallery of Modern Art offers a stunning display of artworks within the former residence of the Lorraine family on the second floor of the palace.

sources.snippet: The walkways around the Palace are the perfect backdrop to act like the king or queen that you are!. The inside of the palace is where you start to understand how this made our list of Instagrammable spots in Florence. Artwork and statues covering the walls, art fresco on the ceiling, and gold leaf everywhere you look.
sources.shortName: 29 Instagrammable Spots in Florence

sources.snippet: Not only is the Palazzo Pitti incredibly historic, but it‚Äôs also fully deserving of its entry of a list of the most instagrammable places in Florence.
sources.shortName: The 22 Must-See Instagrammable Places in Florence!

places.name: Palazzo Pitti

reviews.text:
We got to visit this place for free during their doors open on the first Sunday. Got there very early so there weren't any line ups but once we came out it was very long.

The historical building and art is very pretty! The garden is nice and open.

We only had about two hours spare and we chose to see the Modern Art exhibit‚Ä¶ not modern art as one would normally expect to see‚Ä¶ modern Italian art (1700s- early 1900s) would be more accurate. On a very hot day, it was a refuge from the sun and if we had more time, it would have been good to see more!

We recently had the chance to visit the stunning Palazzo Pitti and its breathtaking Galleria Palatina in Florence.

The exterior already impresses with its bold Renaissance symmetry and monumental scale ‚Äì but stepping inside is like entering a different world. Lavishly decorated rooms, dazzling chandeliers, and finely detailed ceilings create a royal atmosphere that leaves you speechless. Every space is filled with precious artworks, marble sculptures, and golden frames that catch the light in magical ways.

The gallery itself is a treasure trove of Italian masters ‚Äì Raphael, Titian, Caravaggio ‚Äì displayed in opulent halls that reflect the taste and power of the Medici and beyond. It's more than a museum. It's an experience of beauty, history, and magnificence woven together.

Take your time, look up often ‚Äì and let this place transport you.

Enjoy your stay here and have a fantastic time! üëã

places.generalDescription: Boboli Gardens, located behind the Pitti Palace, have been a serene retreat for centuries. The Medici family transformed the gardens into a stunning Italian-style oasis, setting an example for European courts. The open-air museum is adorned with Renaissance statues, fountains like Neptune Fountain and the large Statue of Abundance, and a grand avenue lined with cypress trees and statues leading to Isolotto square.

sources.snippet: The Boboli Gardens are referenced in many guidebooks and things to do in Florence books thanks to the fact that their elevated position on the other side of the River Arno lends itself to a fantastic view of Florence. Unfortunately, the gardens have certainly seen better days, though we particularly loved seeing the miniature vineyard at the very top of the garden. Entrance tickets to the Boboli Gardens also allow free entrance to the adjacent Bardini Gardens, making a ticket more worth it.

sources.snippet: Designed by the famous Italian architect and designer, Filippo Brunelleschi, the original Palazzo Pitti was built in the 15th century for the Pitti family. The palace was greatly enlarged in the 16th century when it was sold to the Medici family. Today, Palazzo Pitti houses some of the most impressive art collections in Florence, including the Palatine Gallery and the Gallery of Modern Art.

sources.snippet: We‚Äôve included Pitta Palace and Boboli Gardens together as the entrance to Pitti Palace includes entrance to the incredible Boboli Gardens located to the rear of the palace. places.name: Boboli Gardens

reviews.text:
Beautiful gardens with tall, ancient trees and lovely paths for a leisurely stroll.

Keep in mind that most of the paths don't have shade, so in summer it can get very hot. Be sure to bring water, a hat, and anything else you might need to stay cool and comfortable.

Really a park, quite steep in places but there are more gently inclining paths to use and shaded tunnels.  I visited 30 years ago and trees have grown up somewhat blocking the view of the duomo from the coffee house (by the way its not a cafe).  Struggled to find another viewpoint in the heat.  Would recommend visiting early in the day or late afternoon in high summer.  Worth going for the view of Florence but that is about all.  10 euro entry fee.

During our vacation in Florence we decided to visit the Boboli Gardens to escape the fuss of the city for one day.
The garden itself is not too big and therefore walkable. Everything you can find here is within 10 minutes walking. There are several public restrooms and plenty of places you can take a pause on a bench. There is also a beautiful view over the Tuscan landscape (I forgot the name of the place where you have this view).

Something people should be aware of is that they are currently renovating certain parts of the garden. For this reason, certain parts are closed or might ruin the experience of a beautiful looking garden. The fountains were not working as well.

Another point that should be pointed out is that everyone (also the people who only visit the garden), will have to go to security (which means you also go through a metal detector).

The only drawback I found is that the employees working here are not that friendly. This is something that had been pointed out by other people as well, so I am not entirely surprised. The employees gave me the feeling that they did not enjoy working here.

The garden was worth seeing but I am not sure whether it is worth a repeat for in the future.

places.generalDescription: Giardino delle Rose is a charming green space located below the popular Piazzale Michelangelo in Florence. This 19th-century rose garden boasts over 400 varieties of roses that bloom beautifully in late spring, creating a fragrant and colorful display. The garden also features a dedicated Japanese garden and aromatic lemon trees, providing a peaceful retreat from the bustling city.

sources.snippet: Speaking of the gardens of Oltrarno, I am obsessed with a good rose garden!. I grow my own roses on my balcony (though some fare better than others üôÉ) and I love to see how they can be used in landscapes and manicured gardens. There are a lot of fantastic gardens in Florence, like the Medici‚Äôs Giardino di Boboli, but it‚Äôs imposing in size and I didn‚Äôt have that much time for my own photo tour of Florence.
sources.siteName: Notes From Here | Europe Travel Blog
sources.shortName: The 10 Most Instagrammable Spots in Florence ‚Äî Notes From Here

sources.snippet: Giardino delle Rose is located about midway through the flight of stairs going up to Michelangelo‚Äôs Square. The park offers amazing city views and it‚Äôs especially photogenic when its many roses bloom. Right by the entrance, you can find two famous artworks named ‚ÄúPartir‚Äù (a frame-shaped suitcase through which the city‚Äôs skyline is visible) and ‚ÄúJe me souviens‚Äù (a man on a bench near which you can sit).
sources.shortName: 20 Best Florence Instagram Spots

sources.snippet: While the Boboli Gardens are the most well-known of the many gardens dotting the city, many people pass right by this charming rose garden on their way up to Piazzale Michelangelo without even realizing it‚Äôs there. The Giardino delle Rose is at its best in spring when the roses are in bloom, but you can visit any time of year to enjoy the view at one of the best places to take photos in Florence.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Places to Take Photos in Florence

sources.snippet: But it‚Äôs all filthy lies, because I actually am promising you a rose garden!. And you can double it up with a trip to the Piazzale Michelangelo, as it‚Äôs on the way there ‚Äì if you walk up or down the flight of steps located just to the south of the Piazzale, you‚Äôll notice a little doorway set into the wall on the side. Pop in, and you‚Äôll find this rather lovely little garden!
sources.shortName: The 22 Must-See Instagrammable Places in Florence!

sources.snippet: In 1865, when the capital of Italy was moved from Turin to Florence, this beautiful rose garden was commissioned. The best time to visit is in the spring when the roses are in full bloom, and their fragrance permeates the air. This garden will offer one of the best views overlooking the whole city.
sources.shortName: 29 Instagrammable Spots in Florence

sources.snippet: The Rose Garden is a hop and skip away from Ponte Vecchio on the other side of the Arno River. As you can imagine, the garden is popular among couples so don‚Äôt be surprised if you witness some smooching on the lawn. There is no entrance fee and the garden is open year-round from 9 am to sunset.
sources.shortName: 8 Places to Visit for the Best Views in Florence in Italy

sources.snippet: Here you can spend some time relaxing on the lawn overlooking Florence. Among flower beds, ancient walls and breathtaking sceneries, you‚Äôll find tons of good places for photography in Florence.
sources.shortName: Top 5 Spots for photography in Florence // PhotographerTuscany.com

places.name: Giardino delle Rose

reviews.text:
This is an absolutely lovely spot, perfect for a picnic! Bring a blanket, buy a takeaway pizza, and enjoy the beautiful view over Florence. It's a great place for a first date.

There's live music coming from the caf√© above, which adds to the relaxed vibe. You can buy drinks there (an Aperol Spritz in a plastic cup was ‚Ç¨7) and bring them down to the park. They also sell water refills for ‚Ç¨2, so bring your own bottle if you can.

Just a heads-up: the park closes at 8 PM sharp, and they do lock the gates - we know a few people who got to learn this the hard way.
Gorgeous displays of numerous different roses. Lovely views over the Arno to the city and cute cameo views of the Duomo. But not as magnificent as those in England.

Very large and lovely garden which comprises of multiple gardens and lovely sites in Florence. I got tired of walking at a point so didn't get the full view of the location. Will definitely recommend you give atleast 4hours to explore this holistically

places.address: Viale Giuseppe Poggi, 2, 50125 Firenze FI, Italy

places.generalDescription: Ponte Santa Trinita, also known as St Trinity Bridge, is a charming old stone bridge in Florence that crosses the River Arno. It was designed by Bartolomeo Ammanati and reconstructed after World War II. The bridge is adorned with lovely statues and is surrounded by two other stone bridges, Ponte Alla Carraia and the famous Ponte Vecchio.

sources.snippet: While the Ponte Vecchio is the most famous bridge, I think the best images are actually not from the bridge itself, but from the neighbouring bridges of Ponte alle Grazie and Ponte alle Trinita. So instead of trying to take images from Ponte Vecchio or the surrounding banks, head straight to either of the other bridges to capture the Ponte Vecchio in all its glory. Ponte alle Trinita (or Trinity Bridge) is my personal favourite as it gives the best images of Ponte Vecchio with the backdrop of Piazza Michelangelo on the hill in the background.
sources.siteName: The Whole World Is A Playground
sources.shortName: The Best Photo Locations in Florence (with map)

sources.snippet: While not many people know that the Trinity Bridge is the oldest elliptic arch bridge in the world (save that fun fact to impress your friends üòâ), it is popular for being one of the best photo spots for a view of its neighbour, the Ponte Vecchio!. It‚Äôs one of our favourite Instagrammable spots for a photobomber-free shot of the pastel Italian buildings lining the sparkling Arno River. Photo: Camilla in Florence for Flytographer.Sheryl and friends celebrate a trip to Florence with a friends photoshoot at Ponte Vecchio and Ponte Santa Trinita.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Places to Take Photos in Florence

sources.snippet: Ponte Santa Trinita is the first bridge past the famous Ponte Vecchio and Ponte alla Carraia is the second. I‚Äôm in love with these bridges for their beautiful street lamps and of course the spectacular view of Ponte Vecchio and the picturesque buildings lining the Arno river. The location is also close to Piazzale degli Uffizi and Piazza della Signoria, both incredible locations that compliment any Florence photo session.
sources.shortName: Photoshoot Locations in Florence, Italy - Top 10

sources.snippet: The Ponte Santa Trinita is another one of Florence‚Äôs iconic bridges. It crosses the Arno River just south of the Ponte Vecchio and is named for the church of Santa Trinita which is located on the other side of the river. The bridge was built in the 16th century and is a popular spot for photographers and tourists alike since it offers some of the best views of the Ponte Vecchio bridge.
sources.shortName: 20 Best Florence Instagram Spots

sources.snippet: This is pretty much the famous view you see of the Ponte Vecchio in postcards and other photos online, and there‚Äôs a reason for it - it‚Äôs a great view!. I spent a couple of sunsets shooting here and you can also turn around to look upriver for a slightly different perspective on the town. This spot is upriver from the Ponte Vecchio by 1 bridge.
sources.shortName: Top Photo Spots in Florence, Italy

sources.snippet: Known as one of the most beautiful bridges in Italy and one of the most elegant in Europe, Ponte Santa Trinita has ancient origins and the current appearance is from a 1958 remodel. The original was destroyed during the Second World War. From here you can see the colours reflected on the Arno and the rays of sun that cross the bridge.
sources.shortName: Instawalk: The most Instagram-worthy places in Florence

sources.snippet: Not only is this bridge the oldest elliptic bridge in the world, but it also offers the best view of the Ponte Vecchio. If you are looking for a photo with Ponte Vecchio as your backdrop, this bridge is your ideal photo-taking spot. Featured Traveler: @nathalie_wanders
sources.shortName: 29 Instagrammable Spots in Florence

sources.snippet: I think that the view east from Ponte Santa Trinit√† trumps those from Ponte Vecchio. This is in no small part thanks to the view that you get of Ponte Vecchio. Featuring graceful arches and stone decorations, Ponte Santa Trinit√† itself is a stunner.
sources.shortName: 13 Stunning Views Of Florence You'll Adore

places.name: Ponte Santa Trinita

reviews.text: The bridge is often considered the most elegant and architecturally refined stone bridge spanning the Arno River, representing the height of Renaissance bridge design. Notably, it is the world's first elliptical arch bridge, composed of three shallow elliptical arches. Originally built as a wooden bridge in 1252, it was reconstructed in stone after a flood in 1333. After collapsing again in 1557, the current version was built between 1567 and 1571, commissioned by Cosimo I de' Medici and designed by Bartolomeo Ammannati. Destroyed in 1944 during World War II, the bridge was meticulously rebuilt in 1958 using the original materials and plans. At night, the softly lit arches reflected in the river create a picture-perfect, romantic scene.

Views are amazing! The first time I visited I went at sunset time and it was very crowded but it's still beautiful. The second time I woke up for sunrise and I was literally the only one overlooking at both of the bridges. So lucky to be here! üåÅ üåÑ üáÆüáπ

Elegantly arched, timeless beauty over the Arno
This Renaissance masterpiece, designed by Bartolomeo Ammannati (with Michelangelo's possible input), was built between 1567‚Äì1569 on the site of older medieval bridges  . It holds the title of the world's oldest elliptical‚Äëarch bridge, featuring three flattened arches (29‚ÄØm outer spans, 32‚ÄØm center) meticulously carved from limestone  .

places.address: 50100 Firenze FI, Italy

places.generalDescription: Loggia dei Lanzi, also known as Loggia della Signoria, is a 14th-century open-air gallery of Renaissance sculpture located in Piazza della Signoria in Florence. This ceremonial building with wide arches houses important Renaissance art and has been a part of the city since 1382. The area was used to display sculptures as a political message next to Florence's seat of power during the rule of the Grand Duchy of Tuscany.

sources.snippet: The political heart of Florence, Piazza della Signoria is home to the city‚Äôs town hall, Palazzo Vecchio. It‚Äôs a common meeting place for locals and tourists alike, especially those meeting up for a tour of the Uffizi Gallery, which is just a short walk nearby. There are a lot of photo opportunities in Piazza della Signoria, from the Fountain of Neptune to the statues near the entrance of Palazzo Vecchio.
sources.siteName: Notes From Here | Europe Travel Blog
sources.shortName: The 10 Most Instagrammable Spots in Florence ‚Äî Notes From Here

sources.snippet: The Loggia dei Lanzi is an open-air gallery in Piazza della Signoria, that houses a collection of statues and sculptures. The gallery is open from 8 am to 7 pm daily and it‚Äôs free to visit.
sources.shortName: 20 Best Florence Instagram Spots
Instagram Guide to Capturing Stunning Photos in Florence

places.name: Loggia dei Lanzi

reviews.text: The Loggia dei Lanzi is an open-air museum in the heart of Florence, and it's absolutely captivating! The stunning arches and the impressive collection of sculptures, including Perseus with the Head of Medusa, are remarkable. It's the perfect spot to admire art and history while enjoying the vibrant atmosphere of Piazza della Signoria. A must-visit for any art lover!
A beautiful piazza with replicas of statues.  The Perseus statue is the original and one I most wanted to see and it was stunning.  I highly recommend stopping by to admire the sculptures!

The Loggia dei Lanzi is a stunning open-air sculpture gallery right on Piazza della Signoria. It's like stepping into a live history lesson-every corner is filled with incredible Renaissance and classical statues, including Cellini's Perseus with the Head of Medusa and Giambologna's Rape of the Sabine Women.

Being outdoors makes it easy to admire the details up close, and the open arches give a beautiful frame for photos of the surrounding piazza. The atmosphere is lively yet contemplative, blending art, history, and Florence's city life in one spot.

places.address: P.za della Signoria, 50121 Firenze FI, Italy

places.generalDescription: La Terrazza Sul Duomo Firenze is a charming B&B with a rooftop terrace that offers breathtaking views of the famous Duomo in Florence. Guests can enjoy the stunning panorama while sipping on a glass of wine. The property provides clean and spacious rooms, with attention to detail and a limited number of rooms for an intimate experience. The central location makes it convenient for exploring the city, and the reception staff are accommodating.

sources.snippet: B&B La Terrazza Sul Duomo offers guests a truly amazing panorama. The property‚Äôs rooftop terrace provides stunning views of Florence‚Äôs famous Duomo and is the perfect spot to enjoy a glass of wine. When I was planning my second trip to Florence, I was a tad bit disappointed to discover that the B&B was not available for the dates of our trip, but maybe next time will be in luck.
sources.shortName: 20 Best Florence Instagram Spots

sources.snippet: If you‚Äôre looking for a cute bed and breakfast with Italian flair this is the place to go!. This historical building sits right beside the main square in Florence. Once you get over your charming Italian room, head up to the rooftop terrace.
sources.shortName: 29 Instagrammable Spots in Florence

places.name: La Terrazza Sul Duomo Firenze

reviews.text: I highly recommend this amazing hotel! The location is perfect, right in the city center, and everything is within walking distance ‚Äì super convenient. The room was stunning, beautifully decorated, and spacious ‚Äì a truly comfortable place to stay. There's also an elevator, which is definitely a plus. Daniel, the manager, was incredibly kind and welcoming ‚Äì the service was exceptional. Additionally, there's an option to go up to the rooftop, where you can enjoy a breathtaking view of the entire historic Florence ‚Äì truly a magical experience. Highly recommended"

La Terrazza Sul Duomo Firenze is a true gem in the heart of Florence! The rooftop terrace offers absolutely stunning views of the Duomo-an unforgettable spot to relax and soak in the beauty of the city. The rooms are quaint, charming, and comfortable, perfectly reflecting the character of Florence. Its central location made it easy to explore all the main sights on foot. A wonderful stay we'll always remember!

We spent four nights in the apartment with a terrace. While the view from the community rooftop was beautiful and the location was perfect, other aspects of our stay fell short of expectations. The accommodations felt more like a VRBO or Airbnb rather than a hotel.

There was noticeable mold growth throughout the bathroom ceiling and shower, and only one set of towels was provided for our entire stay. The building did have a potent smell throughout it. The staff member who welcomed us was not very friendly, though the one we met upon departure was much more pleasant.

Additionally, the terrace access was shared with all other guests, making the extra cost for a ‚Äúprivate‚Äù apartment view feel misleading. The photos and descriptions did not clearly convey this.

Overall, we wouldn't recommend this apartment. It was not worth the extra expense.

places.address: Via Roma, 3, 50122 Firenze FI, Italy

places.generalDescription: The Gates of Paradise are a set of famous golden doors located at the Baptistery of St. John in Florence. Created by Lorenzo Ghiberti in the mid-15th century, these bronze doors stand at 16.6 feet tall and weigh approximately 3 tons. While replicas now adorn the Baptistery, the original doors can be found at the Museo dell'Opera del Duomo nearby.

sources.snippet: This is the main gate to the Baptistry of Florence, located in front of the Cathedral of Santa Maria del Fiore. Made entirely of bronze and weighing about three tons, this 17-foot tall door has ten gold painted panels depicting the Old Testament. It‚Äôs most definitely worth a quick visit to get a shot in front of the Gates of Paradise.
sources.shortName: 29 Instagrammable Spots in Florence

sources.snippet: While these doors hanging on the Baptistery are actually a replica of the originals, you will want to check them out here just because they are beautiful and detailed. They are generally crowded with people taking shots, but if you are patient (or arrive at off hours) you can get a clean shot.
sources.shortName: Top Photo Spots in Florence, Italy

sources.snippet: The Gates of Paradise stand at the entrance of the Baptistery which is also near the Florence Cathedral. These detailed gates marked the beginning of the famous Renaissance period and gives visitors a unique look at a moment in history.
sources.shortName: Best Photography Spots in Florence Italy

places.name: The Gates of Paradise

reviews.text:
Interesting history of this "Gates of Paradise" of the Baptistery of St John, in front of the Florence Cathedral, which can be viewed from outside.

The Gates of Paradise or Porta del Paradiso are the famous golden doors of the Baptistery of St. John, with panels depicting Biblical scenes.

These are replicas of Ghiberti's original eastern doors of the baptistry that are currently housed in the Duomo musuem. I found these to be solemn and a work of high art considering that they are very detailed and a fruit of 27 years of hard work. Don't miss these if you are visiting Il Duomo as they stand right in front of it but in an easy to overlook spot.

Beautiful craftsman ship. Even though these are a replica the impression from the size and the gorgerous golden reliefs of stories from the Old Testament are still a sight to behold. You can't miss it them  as you visit the front of the Basilica of Santa Maria Novella. The originals has wisely been moved inside to the Opera del Duomo Museum.

places.address: Piazza del Duomo, 50122 Firenze FI, Italy

places.generalDescription: Nestled in the heart of Florence, Mercato del Porcellino is a captivating 16th-century loggia that once served as a marketplace for luxury goods. Known historically as the Loggia del Mercato Nuovo, this vibrant spot is steeped in rich tales, including its past role in public shaming.

sources.snippet: Between The Duomo and The Ponte Vecchio you will pass by this little market, which isn‚Äôt really that big of a deal, but I just like it for some reason. There is this big sculpture of a wild boar or pig or whatever, and everyone puts a coin in his mouth and lets it drop into the grate below. I believe it is a good luck ritual of sorts and that is ensures a return visit to Florence.
sources.shortName: Top Photo Spots in Florence, Italy

sources.snippet: In between taking some instagrammable shots, rub the nose of the Porcellino statue for good luck!. Good luck aside, the Porcellino statue still makes a great photo opportunity, and the Mercato Nuovo it is located right next to is another excellent opportunity to get some shots of leather goods and souvenirs.
sources.shortName: 21+ Most Instagrammable Photo Spots in Florence

places.name: Loggia del Mercato Nuovo

reviews.text:
Lovely little market in the heart of Florence offering hand made leather goods, silk scarves and a few other types of items.

There's a brass statue of a hog that people were rubbing and slotting coins in its mouth.. not sure of the significance as there wasn't a transcript explaining but it seemed like a fun tradition.

I think it's a cool experience to visit the small statue there. From what I understood, you rub a coin on the outside of its mouth, then let it slide down its tongue, aiming for it to land in the lines below. Just be careful-there are people around who try to steal the coins, so make sure yours goes all the way inside.

Aside from that, the area offers a wide variety of leather goods, including bags, belts, and wallets. Be sure to check that it's real leather to avoid getting scammed.

Lastly, I bought a bag from @famiglia Meucci, and they were amazing! They took the time to explain the entire process in detail. I'm leaving their Instagram here in case you want to check them out or get in touch.

Delightful Building!
I really liked this architecture for a tiny market! This was really a discovery and I personally really enjoyed visiting this place!

places.address: Piazza del Mercato Nuovo, 5 R, 50123 Firenze FI, Italy
